Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (statutes governing divorce, custody and related matters), including the Court’s continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting arrangements;

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, \u00a7 39.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, § 39 (statutory obligations concerning protection of children and reporting);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215 and other provisions conferring jurisdiction and powers on the Probate and Family Court to issue orders for the care, custody and protection of minors.

Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: Applicable case law recognizes that modification of a custody order requires a showing of a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the children and that the child’s best interests govern the modification determination.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel is a U.S. Supreme Court substantive due process/grandparent-visitation case, not a custody‑modification case. The opinion does not discuss the standard for modifying an existing custody order, does not require a showing of material change in circumstances, and only references “best interests” in critiquing a Washington nonparent visitation statute. It therefore does not establish or affirm the proposition that modification of a custody order requires a material change in circumstances and that best interests govern the modification decision.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “Section 26.10.160(3)…provides: ‘Any person may petition the court for visitation rights at any time including, but not limited to, custody proceedings. The court may order visitation rights for any person when visitation may serve the best interest of the child whether or not there has been any change of circumstances.’ … The Washington nonparental visitation statute is breathtakingly broad.”
